												I was not epxecting much out of this game. But I was surprised in a good way. This game offered what I didn't think it would. But for now here is the basic pros and cons of this game:*Positives*-free to play-licenses for all teams (unlike PES)-simple and clean UI-Very well written dialogue for the in-game commentaries-Player biography and faces add authenticity to the game*Negatives*-there is no 2D map to watch your players play like in Football Manager-no soundtrack leaves you sort of audiably bored-a ton of microtransactions (expected from a free to play)-more customizations are necessary-no steam overlay-no achievements,mods,trading cards,etc. (will probably be added later)Overall, the game is superb for being a free to play. But like all free to plays there are always the microtransactions which will hinder the game's experience.Updates in the future may fix the aforementioned negatives but the game offers  so much and all you have to offer is nothing. If you dont pay the microtransactions its not the end of the world because you can still end up in your goal but it might take longer.Having all the licenses and player biographies/faces is quite impressive for a free to play whereas big corporations like Konami still struggle to get licenses.So get this game and try it out. For me I will give this game a pretty solid 7.5/10. The game is great for a free to play but there are some hindering qualities that will hopefully update soon. But for now try it for yourselves!

												A free football manager game? But is it any good? And just how 'free' it is? Keep reading to find out. (or you know, download it yourself, you lazy bum.)Pros:- Lots of official team data, if you've ever cared about football, you can easily find your favorite players and clubs.- Variety in teams, play around with the budget and players of a world-class club or try your best in saving a bottom-tier, financially ruined team from relegation.- From tactics and lineups to managing individual training routines, searching new players, upgrading team facilities, you can do everything but play football itself. (and I'm finding all that entertaining for some odd reason...)- You can observe games in real time, even request substitutions and changes to tactics during matches, so you actually feel like you want to prepare your team for every game.- Plenty of realism and chances to affect your team's performance... (finding the best tactic for your players, individual health, morale and skill levels, players age and retire eventually...)Cons:-Some of the menus are a bit clunky, for an example, I'd love to have a way viewing individual stats without going back and forth between the player data and tactics screens- Virtually no graphics, even matches themselves are simulated with sports commentary -style text notes. Is it pay to win?Not really. You can play with high-level teams that win most of their games anyhow and even teams at the bottom of the predicted rankings can squeeze out wins with proper managament. The cash shop options are definitely there but it's not like they're actively locking away your chances to enjoy the game.

sound.Literally the game is on mute.I understand the game is new on Steam and it only started as a browser/mobile game,but everything about it seems so basic.The transfers aspect of the game is odd to for one week maximum.Also,the game doesn't have the Europa League as the second competition in Europe,there are no national teams,no club tournament between continents,you cannot choose your friendly but they will say that ''a move to your club is not beneficial for their carreers.''I played with Steaua Bucharest and reached the Quarter Finals of Champions League.I had waaay better players in my 												For my full review check out it out on my video game blog  Game On! [chrisspeerswrites.wordpress.com] Soccer Manager vs Football Manger  Soccer Manager 2015  Fun Rating:  7/10 Pros:  F2P; Simple; Nostalgia; Updated Rosters; Quick Gameplay Cons:  Simple; Feels like a Beta game Price:  Free to Play Football Manager 2014  Fun Rating:  9/10 Pros:  Very in-depth; 3D matchs (rather than just word commentary); Realistic transfer system and wage negotiations; Data editor Cons:  Very in-depth; Too many interviews Price:  $50 (got mine for $25 at Green Man Gaming) How Do You Dethrone a King??  There really is no debate. Football Manager is better than Soccer Manager. It has more depth, options, and has been around a lot longer. It also costs more. A lot more. Especially for those “faithful” fans that buy every year’s new iteration that only contains minor updates. This just baffles me, whether it’s FM, Madden, or NBA 2K. $60 every year for the same game? Rarely do such sport franchises make any earth shattering changes that in my opinion justify buying it every single year. Roster changes don’t count as earth shattering in my book. I own Football Manager 2014 and have played 562 hours on it and I could happily play it for several more years before needing to purchase the latest iteration. Especially since it comes with a data editor that many people are willing to make those updated roster changes for you. So, how do you dethrone this ruthless tyrant that has a stranglehold on the soccer (ahem, football for most of the world) simulation management industry? Free and Simple!  Make it free-to-play (F2P), simple to play, and as an added bonus, make it similar to the very first versions of the ruthless king, like back when he was a charming prince. Soccer Manager has a very Championship Manager (Football Manager was initially called Championship Manager before a split between the developers and publisher) feel to it. My first introduction to sports sims was Championship Manager 2 back in 1995 so there’s definitely a bit of nostalgia that helps boost Soccer Manager in a positive manner. It also is F2P and has updated rosters. Since I “only” have FM2014 I was able to try out my Tottenham club with their latest real world roster without having to shell out another $50. While you do have to pay for certain things like scouting faster and additional load/save slots, none of them will stop you from playing and enjoying the game. One of the great pros of Soccer Manager is that there are very few media interviews!! Football Manager, in attempting to make you feel like you really are the manager on the sidelines, has created a very “un-fun” process of 20 questions (the answers to which impact how your players will perform so you better answer them correctly!!) before each match and several after the match, and some more questions for you to answer when you’re not in a match, just because, that’s what managers have to deal with! Well, I just want to buy players and play matches! Soccer Manager gets you back to the basics. Yes, Football Manager does have a Classic mode, which is what I exclusively use now, but it just feels like Football Manager has gotten away from what their game used to be about. Final Verdict!  Football Manager just hasn’t had much competition lately and maybe that is the reason why each version since 2012 seems to be getting worse and worse based on reviews and complaints that I’ve read. So if anything Soccer Manager will push Football Manager to be better. At the end of the day, Football Manager is better than Soccer Manager. But, Soccer Manager is free and with updated rosters, so give it a shot!!

												I recommend this game (in single player mode).It's free-to-play, has a reasonable amount of depth, decent amount of immersion owing to IRL player names and even though it's odd seeing most teams playing the same 4-2-3-1 formation game-in, game-out and it's not exactly feature-rich, it is worth a play.The addition of micro-transactions means that, if you so wish, you can speed up some of the in-game experiences such as upgrades and scouting, etc. But there ARE some Soccer Dollars (as I call them) available for achieving certain tasks and reaching milestones, meaning that it isn't necessary to dip into your IRL wallet in order to enjoy this game.It isn't without its flaws: I personally had a bug where, having upgraded my stadium a couple of times, it was no longer possible to upgrade it (even though there were several upgrade stages remaining, the board had for some reason decided that there was no longer a need to do stadium upgrades and, strangely, my upgraded capacity was only availble during non-domestic games). I contacted the SM admin and they told me that it was an error unique to my save game so unfortunately there was nothing that could be done to rectify it, which kinda sucked as I had banked (no pun intended) on those extra few millions in gate receipts etc . But they did promise they would look into it, so hopefully it's been sorted and doesn't cause issues for others. Apart from this my only other gripe is that it can get a little tedious (but that's probably just the nature of the beast, so to speak): having played through a few seasons I had to take break - the fact that you only get one save slot means you can't mix things up by managing different teams, which would help to keep things interesting. But having said that, you can pay a few quid to upgrade to 'VIP' status which, along with a few other benefits, grants you two extra save game slots (this is something I'm considering, as £3 for what is a decent football management game is still a steal and I don't want to delete my current data - despite the bug - but would like to manage lower league/European teams as well).One other recurring bug I noticed was the absence of ratings for players who had been brought on as substitutes. Even when they'd come on at half-time. Also, I'm not quite sure why it's necessary to pay Soccer Dollars to reveal the Potential ratings of players who are already on the books, given that the scouts seem to be able to give at least a somewhat accurate Potential rating when they've been assigned a scouting assignment. For players of other clubs? Sure. But not for your own players.  Perhaps after they've been with your club for a period of time (3 months, or w/e) you get a report about their Potential. You shouldn't have to pay Soccer Dollars for that... maybe a special fee to the scouting team (using in-game currency)... that would be more understandable, but not Soccer Dollars.I do enjoy playing this game but I'd like to see more information made available, especially more in-depth historic data (previous season's match details etc). The ability to scout for new members off staff would be nice as well (I'd get my current Assistant Manager scouting for his own replacement, just to be a c* lol).Also, more scouting options for the scouts - so things like an age range, multiple positions (for searching out players who have multi-role abilities), ratings range (including being able to instruct the scout to only report back with players who meet a specified minimum Potential rating, etc). And also, more in-depth match reports, including entire match narratives and individual player reports for each game (not just the overall details you get access to in your 'office').Overall, this game is worth a play and I think its large player base is testament to that. I've read unflattering things about the multiplyer aspect (it sounds like it needs some adjustments made to make it fairer on newcomers) but I haven't accessed this aspect of the game and can only give my opinion, therefore, on the single player campaign which is, despite a few bugs, well worth the asking price - £0.My story:I played through as the team I have been a fan of since a youth - Chelsea.My first job as manager was to put John Terry on the trasnfer list (it was so cathartic, but I kinda regretted being a c* to him given his legend status at the club, but he was a bit of a d*head sooo....). He got picked up by Southampton (an ironic location, given his previous misgivings). Along with him for the ride was Costa, for whom I collected £53m+. Pedro also left, but for Spurs.I brought in Stones, Coman and Koke (who all made more-than-fitting replacements) along with Kante and Meyer, to bolster the squad.My first season was probably my most enjoyable. Despite only finishing 5th in the league, I'd managed to steer the club to League Cup success and, more impressively, Champions League winner's medals having seen off Barcelona (1-0, 1-0) in the Quarters; Bayern Munich (4-1, 4-0) in the Semis; and Real Madrid (2-1) in the Final. I couldn't believe it! I still remember those games: shutting out the most offensive team on the planet; outplaying the most efficient; and outshining football's brightest stars on Europe's biggest stage to top it all off. I had to take a breather after that :)I came back the following season to pick up another League Cup, and this time added a Premier League title but couldn't add another Champions League, having been beaten at my own game by a well drilled PSG in the quarters (I forget the exact scores, but they were close, something like 1-1, 0-1).On my third outing, I picked up only a League title owing to some really awful displays culminating in early exits in all of the other competitions... ugh ¬_¬Seasons played: 3League titles: 2League cups: 2English cups: 0Europa Leagues: 0Champions Leagues: 1\o/For my next challenge I think I'll take on a role at Accrington Stanley."Who are they?" I hear you ask....Exactly.10/10Would transfer list John Terry again.

												Cons:- Can't loan out players... (no offers, ever)- No sound (but option to mute - handy)- Because you can't loan out, youth academy is useless. - Chairman limits you from making decisions constantly, even when they are logical. For example, he once prevented me from selling a player who's wages were eating into my funds (we'll get onto that in a second). Neither was I permitted to release him. Other times he prevents you from selling young players, constantly has unrealistic expectations for your squad whatever their state, etc.- Economy sucks - you have "less" - or as I prefer: ZERO control over your income. You cannot upgrade your stadium easily and you don't seem to attract higher attendance even with fantastic results. Player wages eat up the majority of your funds and while the transfer market is closed, and you are warned to "ensure you have a positive balance" to sign new players, you will come to learn that you aren't a manager - you ain't♥♥♥♥♥♥ you're just a plaything for the chairman.^ If that isn't enough, 95% of the time players on the transfer list won't buy for less than 125-50% of their value, yet the offers you receive for players are normally ~75% of the player's worth.- Results seem to be very random as I was constantly beating the top sides of my division 2-0, then losing 1-4 to Mansfield Town the following day - same team, same tactics, same fitness. Odd. Sure, there can be randomness, but it just seems too random.- You cannot choose friendlies and are obliged to do the ones assigned.- Moral is BS, you cannot improve it in some cases even when playing players every game in correct positions. - Contracts cannot be changed, and never expire; players cannot be congratulated (and rarely punished) for their performance or conduct. It's because of this that there is no connection between you, the manager, and your "squad". Zilch. None. Nothing. Sad.- I DON'T WANT TO SHARE WITH FRIENDS, THEY COULDN'T CARE LESS IF I BEAT SWINDON 3-1 AT COUNTRY GROUND (these "encouraging" messages are constant)- The shop. Bad idea. Just charge a fiver for the game,What's most frustrating is that with otherwise positive features this could be such a great game.
